column1: Superior is at the western end of Lake Superior in northwestern Wisconsin. Bordered by Saint Louis
column2: Superior
column3: and Allouez bays
column4: the city is framed by two rivers: the Nemadji and the Saint Louis. Superior and the neighboring city across the bay
column5: Duluth
column6: Minnesota
column7: form a single metropolitan area called the Twin Ports. They share a harbor that is one of the most important ports on the Great Lakes. Both cities feature museum ships (SS William A. Irvin in Duluth and SS Meteor in Superior)
column8: devoted to the local maritime heritage. Superior was the final port of call for the SS Edmund Fitzgerald before its sinking on November 10

column1: The first-known inhabitants of what is now Douglas County were Mound Builders. These people appeared on the shores of Lake Superior sometime after the latest glacier receded. They mined copper in the Minong Range and at Manitou Falls on the Black River. They pounded this metal into weapons
column2: implements
column3: and ornaments
column4: some of which were later found buried as grave goods in mounds with their dead. Their civilization was eventually overrun by other tribes
column5: mainly of Muskhogean and Iroquois stock
column6: and they disappeared as a distinct culture in late prehistoric American times.

column1: About the time of the European arrival
column2: the Duluth–Superior region transitioned from being predominately Dakota to being predominately Ojibwa/Chippewa (Anishinaabe)
column3: one of the many Algonquian language people. Under pressure from the Ojibwa
column4: the Dakota moved west. In the Ojibwa oral history
column5: Spirit Island in the Saint Louis River was their "Sixth Stopping Place
column6: where the northern and southern divisions of the Ojibwa nation came together in their westward migration. The City of Superior in the Ojibwe language is called Gete-oodena, meaning Old Town." The Lake Superior Chippewa continued to migrate
column7: with many settling to the east toward Madeline Island
column8: the "Seventh Stopping Place." The Mississippi Chippewa migrated toward what is today Brainerd
column9: Minnesota. (The two populations called both the settlements at Bayfield
column10: Wisconsin and Brainerd as Oshki-oodena ("New Town") in the Ojibwe language).

column1: The first-known Europeans to visit the area were French. In 1618
column2: Étienne Brûlé
column3: a voyager for Samuel de Champlain
column4: coasted along the south shore of Lake Superior where he met the Ojibwa. Upon returning to Quebec
column5: he carried back some copper specimens and a glowing account of the region. In 1632
column6: Champlain’s map was made of the area
column7: showing “Lac Superior de Tracy” as Lake Superior and the lower end shore as “Fond du Lac.” Soon after
column9: while Jesuit missionaries came to convert and learn from the Anishinaabe.

column2: the Hudson's Bay Company
column3: followed by the North West Company in 1787 and later
column4: John Jacob Astor's American Fur Company
column5: maintained trading posts with the Anishinaabe
column6: exchanging European tools and goods for their furs and processed leathers. Settlements developed around the trading posts. Many fur traders
column8: married high-ranking Ojibwa women; both sides considered such marriages part of building alliances between the cultures. Fur trappers
column9: who lived among the Ojibwa for months at a time and ranged throughout their territory
column10: also married Ojibwa women. Their mixed-race children were called Métis by the French Canadians. Many of the men also entered the fur trade
column11: becoming interpreters and guides as well.

column1: Douglas County was organized at the site of one of the major water highways used by early travelers and voyagers of inland America. This water trail
column2: the Bois Brule–St. Croix River Portage Trail
column3: was the most convenient connecting link between Lake Superior and the Mississippi River. The Bois Brule and St. Croix River systems were separated only by a short portage over the Eastern Continental Divide near Solon Springs
column4: Wisconsin. The northward traveler used this water trail reach Lake Superior
column5: while the downstream traveler could use it to go southwest to the Gulf of Mexico
column6: unhindered by portages
column7: by using the St. Croix and Mississippi rivers. This waterway was also an important route in the Wisconsin fur trade
column8: particularly when the French War with the Fox Indians closed the more southern routes.

column2: spurred by the prospect of lucrative shipping on the Great Lakes and exploitation of the iron ore industry
column3: businessmen from Chicago and St. Paul
column4: Minnesota laid claim to the site which became the city of Superior. They planned to lay out the plots of a great city
column5: and attract new European-American settlers for development of the area.

column1: The first log cabin in Superior was erected in September 1853 on the banks of the Nemadji River
column2: at the same time that ground was broken for construction of the locks and ship canal at Sault Ste. Marie
column3: Michigan. This was intended to allow ships to bypass the rapids at that site. Superior was incorporated as a city on September 6
column4: 1854. Around the same time Superior became the seat of newly formed Douglas County. Immediately there was eagerness for a railroad from Lake Superior to the Pacific Coast
column5: and investment flowed in
column6: but then the Panic of 1857 hit
column8: and the population of the new city collapsed from 2500 to 500.Twenty-five years later the Northern Pacific Railway and other rail lines finally arrived
column9: fulfilling the dream of a rail and water highway from coast to coast. In 1883 General John H. Hammond formed the Land and River Improvement Company
column10: which developed much of West Superior
column11: including the West Superior Iron and Steel plant. Numerous grain
column12: coal and lumber businesses formed in the same period.

column1: In the Boom Period from 1888 to 1892
column2: Land and River Improvement and others built impressive architect-designed business blocks on Tower Avenue
column3: seeing Superior as the "new Chicago." Many of the investors were from out East
column4: so the buildings received names like the New Jersey Block and the Maryland Block. By 1892
column5: population was 34
column6: 000. Then the Panic of 1893 hit
column8: the city was heavily settled by migrants from the eastern United States as well as immigrants from over 15 countries

column1: There are several parks in the city
column2: including the second largest municipal forest in the United States
column3: located in the city's Billings Park neighborhood. Pattison State Park is one of two state parks within a short driving distance south of the city. Pattison State Park contains Big Manitou Falls
column4: the highest waterfall in the state at 165 feet (50 m). Amnicon Falls State Park
column5: also a short driving distance from Superior
column6: features a series of waterfalls created by the Douglas Fault.

column1: The Duluth Transit Authority provides Superior and nearby Duluth with fixed-route and dial-a-ride public bus service.Rail
A proposed Amtrak route running between Duluth and the Twin Cities has a planned stop in Superior and is the final stop before arriving in Duluth or the first stop after departing from Duluth.

column1: The transportation industry accounts for more than 1
column2: 000 jobs. The Twin Ports of Duluth–Superior
column3: the largest in the Great Lakes
column4: welcomes both domestic and foreign vessels. Bulk solids (such as grain) make up much of the tonnage handled by the port
column5: and the silos of such port facilities are visible on the Superior waterfront. In 2004
column6: the port's busiest year since 1979
column7: more than 41.4 million metric tons were shipped out of the port. Burlington Northern Railroad has an operations hub in Superior.

column1: Husky Energy operates a refinery in Superior. The refinery is located along a pipeline connecting western Canada and the Midwest. On April 26
column3: there was an explosion at the refinery around 10:00 AM. Douglas County then issued a state of emergency due to heavy smoke. Around 1:00 PM
column4: the county issued evacuation for residents and workers 1 mile (1.6 km) north
column5: 3 miles (4.8 km) east and west
column6: and 10 miles (16 km) south of the refinery. There were 20 initial injuries
column7: and 5 were transported to the hospital in Duluth

Superior is the episcopal see of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Superior
column2: and the Cathedral of Christ the King in Superior is the mother church of the diocese. Saint Francis Xavier Catholic Church
column3: located in the East End of Superior
column4: has been noted for its architecture. Christ Evangelical Lutheran Church is the only congregation of the Lutheran Church Missouri Synod located in Superior. It recently moved from its original location on Belknap Street to a new campus on North 28th Street. Pilgrim Lutheran Church is located along Belknap Street near the University of Wisconsin–Superior. United Presbyterian Church represents the Presbyterian Church U.S.A as a merger of three churches in a new church building. Faith United Methodist Church is the result of a merger of the city's original three Methodist Churches: First
column5: Central and Trinity.  Many small churches dot the city's neighborhoods
column6: representing most major denominations.
